oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joint Protection in Osteoarthritis of the Hand: A Critical Review

foxml:datastreamVersion.LABEL: Joint Protection in Osteoarthritis of the Hand: A Critical Review

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joint Protection in Osteoarthritis of the Hand: A Critical Review
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sarah Leszczynski
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Osteoarthritis
Joint Protection
Hand Function
Occupational Therapist
Therapy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Abstract
Background: With an aging population, an increase in the prevalence of chronic conditions, such as arthritis, is expected. As such, occupational therapists are becoming more involved in providing non-pharmacologic treatment options aimed at improving or maintaining quality of life, to individuals diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the hand. Joint protection is one non-pharmacologic intervention utilized by therapists in client treatment plans. The main goal of joint protection aims to decrease pain and increase function in individuals diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the hand. Purpose: To determine the current level of evidence supporting the use of joint protection in osteoarthritis of the hand in increasing hand function. Methods: A critical review of the literature using the McMaster protocols for quantitative studies and the FAME scale was conducted in order to evaluate the current level of evidence supporting the intervention. Findings: Three studies matching set inclusion and exclusion criteria were reviewed. The level of evidence ranged from weak to moderate. Based on the results, a definitive conclusion regarding the efficacy and use of the intervention in occupational therapy was not clearly defined. Implications: Further, more specific and in depth research is required to determine if joint protection is a worthwhile intervention for occupational therapists to incorporate within treatment plans when looking to increase function for individuals diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the hand.
Keywords: osteoarthritis; joint protection; hand function; occupational therapist; therapy.
